fields.title: Day 140 Rollercoster
fields.content:
This is such a rollercoaster that I am just desperate to get off. After the almost high of the previous day, I have now plummeted worse than I could've imagined!

I went to the hospital to have a coupe of skin biopsies, as the dermatologist wants to discover if there is actually any eczema on my body at all, as it could all be RSS. Whilst it was only a minor operation, I am in so much daily pain with the burning in my face and the whole body soreness, going through a procedure like this, though minor, pushed me over the edge!

I went into the theatre and was told the only real discomfort of the minor op was the administration of the local anaesthetic. Well, they are obviously not used to treating people who's skin does not provide a barrier and when they applied the substance to clean the area, it was agony, it literally burnt like hell.
My skin is raw and this was a horrendous start. I could see they just didn't get it so they injected me and continued with the biopsy.

Again, I reiterate I am already in a state, both mentally and physically, as my day's are just for surviving as best I can so seeing my abdomen covered in blood that they were trying to stop just felt like the lowest point I have had to cope with. They continued and repeated the procedure in my right thigh and once they'd stitched me up told me I couldn't bath for 4-5 day's. I wanted to cry, I was broken! Everybody has a limit to what they take and this was it for me, I just didn't want to continue. For most sufferers that I have come across the bath is one place were their symptoms are momentarily eased. To hear that I couldn't for 4-5 day's was horrendous.

Whilst I know they are doing this for good reasons as they are trying to find some medication that will help, I still struggled to get it together after this.

This is such a tough season, worse than I thought. Through it I know two things are absolutely true.

1. That God is good and only good in all things.
2. I know he can heal.

I am not going to lie, hitting such a low has made these truths difficult to reconcile at times. Sickness is not what God originally intended for our bodies but he can use it and use it for our good. Whilst this is hard to see in the midst of sickness, it remains true! I am obviously broken and in need of his healing and He will make good of this, I just don't know what that is yet. I am reminded that before he went to the cross the Lord Jesus pleaded with the Father to take this cup from him and in the same prayer accepted what The Father wanted to accomplish through the life of his perfect Son.

1 Peter 5:10
And the God of all grace, who called you to his eternal glory in Christ, after you have suffered a little while, will himself restore you and make you strong, firm and steadfast.

fields.title: Day 139
fields.content:
An incredible breakthrough today!

Not in terms of healing, but I went for my 3 month biologics check up at the hospital to be scored, in order to ascertain whether or not I could continue on Dupilumab. I spectacularly failed the test and it looked like I was going to have to stop it. However, once the nurses had finished with their scoring, I went in to see the dermatologist, who listened to what I was saying and the research I had done in terms of 'topical Steroid Addiction(TSA/TSW). He then summoned in 4 additional Dermatologists, who I briefly recounted my history too. The lead dermatologists confirmed 'Red Skin Syndrome' which is the disease that commences once you go into Topical Steroid Withdrawal.
Neither my Mum or I could believe it, what we were hearing felt like a miracle. So often these visits are followed with an instruction to take more and more topical/oral steroids. It felt like such a breakthrough, the dermatologist, who was the clinical lead even gave reasoning for the full body redness and what was happening to my blood vessels. I now have to go back to the hospital to have a skin biopsy to confirm, but it looks like i'll be getting support from now on in!

I feel so blessed by God. So many and I mean so many people suffering with this disease do not get a diagnosis or any support and I have just had 5 dermatologists at the hospital hear about 'Red Skin Syndrome' and NOT deny it's existence. God is with us and never leaves us, though it's tough he will see me through.

Psalm 139 7-10

Where can I go from your Spirit?
Where can I flee from your presence?
If I go up to the heavens, you are there;
if I make my bed in the depths, you are there.
If I rise on the wings of the dawn,
if I settle on the far side of the sea,
even there your hand will guide me,
your right hand will hold me fast.

fields.title: From a 6yr old son.
fields.content: when daddy is feeling beter go fishing.have A play fihgt. sword fihgt. more cudlse.piggy back rides.eat mroe chocolate.bed time cuds.bicker ridse.play in the parck.

fields.title: Sad times
fields.content:
I think it is common for many sufferers to go through bouts of depression and you can understand why.

I have found personally that I get hit with a daily reality check. I often wake up and dream about what I could achieve with a day and then what i am actually going to be able to do hits me like a punch in the face. So many, in fact most of my day's are something i've just got to get through. That often means long salt baths, remaining inside the home and just wearing pyjamas.

I additionally struggle with the burden I have become on my family, particularly my wife, who is so supportive, but even for her it all gets too much and seems to go on forever.

I used to be so active and outgoing, I genuinely loved people and being around them and now even on the odd day I manage to get out I feel like a freak show and try not to look people in the face or make eye contact as I once would.

I find you just can't get a break from the suffering, it doesn't matter how many antihistimine and pain killers I take, if its not one thing it's another. If it's not sore and causing me a burning pain it's flaking off, oozing and itching like crazy. I hate looking at the piles of dust I create from the itching. Although, I do have to admit that I do not ooze like some of accounts I have read, I do get it behind my ears which has made my face stick to the pillow case and in the beginning on the back of my legs, of which my daughter remarked 'have you just got out the shower?'.

On top of this it makes sleep almost impossible unless I take pills which the doctor has told me I shouldn't be taking everyday as I 'll get addicted!
I miss being the husband /dad I was before, I can no longer plan anything and I have had to exclude myself from the last two family holidays.

I miss the bedtime cuddles I used to have with my kids, I am just so sore it would be so uncomfortable to embrace them.

It goes without saying, I cannot wait for the day this is finally through with!

I honestly think these symptoms are enough to drag anyone down, even the happiest most outgoing person in the world.

I know there is an end to this but it feels so far away.

PS

fields.title: Stranger symptoms.
fields.content:
Some of the more unusual symptoms I've experienced so far have been convulsions in my legs. They mainly occur at bedtime and there have been occasions when I have realised I've been having them until I wake up and see my wife leaving the bedroom with a very angry look on her face! I asked her where she was going and she asked me if I was serious and hadn't notice what I'd been doing but apparently I had been kicking my legs repeatedly over the course of about 20 minutes in a convulsing type action.

Another stranger symptom I certainly wasn't expecting is that I have gone from having a fair amount of body hair covering most my body that has all fallen out, almost completely!

fields.title: Day 100
fields.content:
Well, i've made it this far, never thought i could. i am finding it very "
'tough. I cannot sleep without sleeping pills. My face and arms remain '
"horrendous. the doctor told me I shouldn't be using pill everyday but if i "
"don't i will lie awake until the early hours of the morning, it's not "

'roughly have itching episodes 2/3 times per day which are awful. I have '
'managed to put on about 3 kg pretty much due to comfort eating and having '
'become sedentary. My favourite place remains the hot water of the bath!!'

fields.title: Why go through TSW?
fields.content:
Why would anyone go through this harrowing ordeal. Well, the simple answer is that I had no health on the steroids, it was no existence at all. The suffering began literally a day after applying them, red swelling would appear all over my body and i would start to flake off everywhere. In addition, i began experiencing burning pain most commonly around my neck and the inside of my thighs - strange!

Well, the next question to answer is "How do I know it's the steroids?"
I KNOW because I have eliminated every other possibility to try and regain my health. Whatever I tried produced no results, none at all, the painful red skin just keeps coming back!

I have gone through the elimination diets such as no dairy, eggs, alcohol, gluten, processed food, caffeine and no eating out. Our home is as allergy friendly as it possibly could be. We have no carpets, pets, curtains I damp dust and wash all laundry at a minimum of 60 degrees and use non-biological washing powder. We additionally filter the water we drink and shower with. sO i felt that i had covered every base. I also went on immunosupresents yet the problems still continued.
That is when I turned to the google and entered my symptoms and discovered the following web pages:

https://www.itsan.org/
http://www.red-skin-syndrome.com/dr-marvin-rapaport-md/

This is where I found the closest thing to an explanation and honestly it terrified me what I was going to have to undergo to try and get my health back. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to face.

My unknown future is the hands of God, he has given me a body that heals and my trust is in him.

Ephesians 6:10
Finally, be strong in the Lord and in the strength of his might.

I could not face this without God because I seriously don't have the strength to face this on my own, so much suffering and it's so prolonged.

fields.title: My daughter's perspective
fields.content: y Dad had barely any eczema when he was in his 20 and 30s ,but then he got stressed so he used steroids which he thought was good but sadly not. So my dad used stronger and stronger steroids until his skin got worse and worse.We know it is steroids because he did not eat anything bad and he saw a doctor on the internet and he tried everything. Right now my daddy is not only coverd in RED [not pink RED ok] head to toe he is oozing, bleeding and spot things.We can NOT do night walks, cuddle, play in the garden, go on hoiliday [not even to the PARK] and I could go on.It is not fun.It feels like I don't have a real dad.IT feels lonely ,sad and boaring.BY Lily daddys girl.

fields.title: Anxiety/tears
fields.content:
I've only ever heard of one or two other sufferers mentioning this, but I am going to write about it and admit it. I am 37 years old and I am now fearful of the dark, as night falls I feel the fear and anxiety start to flood in. 

Never in my entire life, not even as a kid have I experienced anything like this. This disease is hell and destroying not just my physical health but also my mental. I've just told my wife that this is happening to me and I burst out into floods of tears. Something that has become all too common, it certainly doesn't take much for me to cry at the minute.

 Fear and tears are not something you would associate with a grown up but this is my reality and I thought I should be honest about it so I f anyone ever finds this web page may also find some comfort if they experience this. Right now it just feels like this disease will never leave and it's grip on me is forever.

I have it explained to me that the fear and anxiety come over me as I have become so vulnerable.My existence has become very small, I literally spend my day's in our home and very rarely ever leave other than absolutely having too. 

I am here now sitting with my wife as she goes to sleep so at least some of the night I won't be on my own. This disease doesn't allow for much sleep and the sleep you do get is not great quality. I'm often looking at getting around 3 hours or so which leaves a lot of the night just on my own pottering around while my family sleep.

fields.title: itchy itchy itchy
fields.content:
The itchiness has become increasingly more intense of late. It covers my whole body as does this relentless red skin. The worse areas affected remain on my arms, face, neck and upper torso. Although my legs are not spared and  certainly flare up and down. In addition, I seem to have endless hair follicle infections. 

I take quite a selection of drugs to manage the pain which presents as sharp acute stabbing sensations in addition to the constant pain of being in my skin. I take amitripline and co-codamol. I was also taking naproxen but this is an unhelpful drug as it can give you stomach problems.

I still very rarely get dressed as my whole body is just so sore. Often the pain is triggered just by moving from a sitting to standing position. My cheeks still get a horrendous burning sensation that feels like someone is dripping acid o to the surface of my skin. My wife kindly bought me an ice pack specifically for my face which does help somewhat. 

My wife has dared to come back to share our bed with me again but I am forbidden from going at the same time as her as my scratching stresses her out and the last thing I want to do is disturb her as she is coping with so much. 

I am desperate to be able to hug my kids again, they are growing so fast and I just can't enjoy them. The steroids stole so much. I feel so vulnerable and fear this torment is here to stay. I am approaching seven months now and I know so many people are doing much better than me at this stage which increases my fear that I'm not going to heal.

I very rarely go out for short walks. Predominantly due to the soreness and I dread being seen by people as I just look awful with my red swollen face and flaky skin. 

I've missed so many family trips and holidays and I am so desperate to join them again.

fields.title: 7 months
fields.content:
Well, I have just cleared the seventh month mark or 218 days. I honestly dared to dream I would be doing much better by now. The truth is I am at my lowest. I was taking dupilumab but the dermatologist has stopped it as I wasn't making enough progress on it to justify continuing with such an expensive drug. 

It's a month since I stopped and my red skin covers the entire surface of my body and inflammation is even breaking through the palms of my hands which is agony. I am becoming completely incapacitated, I spend about 6-7 hours minimum per day in the hot water of the bath which is were I get some relief.

I had an emergency appointment with the dermatologist on Friday and had to be taken by my wife as I cannot drive in this state. He was going to start me on a different immunosuppressant drug but my blood pressure was too high so I am going to see him again on Wednesday to see if there is any change. I am in desperate need of help, I just want to be able to function a bit so I don't have to spend the whole day in the bath. 

I still cannot cope with having any company other than my immediate family. It's just too hard and yet I miss people so much. I haven't been able to go even for a short walk, not even around our garden as the pain is just so much.

fields.title: oozing
fields.content:
My arms are extremely swollen and insanely itchy. I am oozing more than ever. It is particularly bad around my face, ears, and neck. My sheets are getting wet at night which is so disgusting. I additionally found it frightening on one occasion I oozed from my arm and drenched two tea towels in the space of 15 minutes.
I started cyclosporin 3 days ago which I hope is going to make a difference. I still have to live in the bath or I start tearing at my skin. I still find myself bursting out crying all the time. I feel so bad for my wife who is having to put up with me through this.

fields.title: Guy's appointment
fields.content: The dermatologist at the hospital decided to refer me to Guy's and St Thomas' hospital back in November. I had an appointment and they admitted me for just under two weeks. The Dermatology Day Centre is brilliant. They started me on a regime of daily bleach baths, coating me in hydromol, antibiotics and a higher dose of cyclosporin. They also attempted to wrap my skin in zinc wraps but my skin was just too sensitive to cope with them as they stung like crazy. These two weeks really helped, the nurses and the doctors there really wanted to help turn things around and I am very grateful to them for all they've done. After my stay there my skin was the clearest it has been in a long time if only it could've lasted! Once I was discharged they scheduled me in for appointments twice per week to keep an eye on things.

fields.title: Will it end?
fields.content:
It just feels like it is never going to stop flaring. I have now been on cyclosporin for just under a year and have been told I have reached the maximum time I should be on it. They have put me on a re-trial of dupilumab and I am starting it whilst reducing the other. I am just finding this disease so violent and hard to get any respite from. I am hoping that the new drug will help. I am also very nervous coming off cyclosporin as it has taken some of the edge off the flaring and I have been able to function to some degree. I have been able to take and collect the children from school on some days, prepare dinner for the family and wear baggy clothing, all things I am grateful for. 

Although, as much as I try to be positive it is hard and having never previously suffered from mental health problems I certainly battle it now. As soon as the flaring starts and I look like a mad man scratching all over I wonder if it is worth carrying on at all. It's hard to fight these mental health problems on top of this skin disease and it's so hard to be positive when I just don't feel like I make the progress others have made. I keep dreaming of milestones when I might be healed but they seem to come an go. I'm now into month 20 and I dared to dream I would be much further along and sometimes my heart just sinks and I feel like this is it for me.

fields.title: Day 785 The itch is in charge!
fields.content:
Well, I certainly thought I would be healed, if not massively improved by now! Part of me can't believe it, however,  It seems I have to accept it. I wish I could say at least the itch had subsided considerably, but literally the only way I can get any relief from it is the shower with the water on the hotter side. It is by far the worst of all the symptoms. The nerve pain, burn, ooze, its smell and the flakiness are disgusting but I can get through them. However, the itch I have experienced with this disease with traumatise me forever, It has a depth and intensity that must be unimaginable to people that are comfortable in their skin. I often feel like I am trying to tear my bones out of my flesh. The itch dominates my life, It determines everything. I do everything I can not see people, such is the fear of being witnessed having a scratching fit.
I have been asked by several people  "what on earth do you do with your days?" I always know that these people have never suffered or been tortured by their body. 

I take cyclospornin, this at least allows me to function to some degree and not have to spend all of my time in the bath. I feel like a lot of fellow sufferers look down on people who choose this course. I have a young family and I need to help my wife even a little bit ,as it's been so long. 

I had my contract terminated from my job of 18 years around month 9 and since then I have not brought any money in to the home. I feel so bad to be putting this sort of pressure on my wife but there is just no way I could hold a job down. I have had it suggested to me to apply for help. Well , I did apply for ESA, PIP and UC. All the institutions that exist to help you out if this sort of tragedy befalls you. Sadly, one by one they all shut the door on me. The ESA were particularly cutting when they told me I just looked a bit flushed and should work. Please have a look at the photo gallery even cotton t-shirts are painful to wear.  I was red all over and burning and itching like crazy. I can't even begin to tell you the fear and anxiety I suffered having to go to that meeting. Why is there no empathy for skin disease out there?

Denise, Lily and Lucas why are you still with me. I would not hold it against you to leave me, I have become utterly grotesque. 
God knows without you I couldn't face another day and unquestionably would not have made it this far.

fields.title: Jak Inhibitors
fields.content:
I thought nothing could ever work or even take the edge of theses horrendous symptoms, other than cyclosporine. 

If you are reading this you will know that in the UK you are only supposed to be on Cyclosporine for a year and in some exceptional circumstances a couple of years. After that they want you off it for fears of renal injury. 

I have failed so many different drug attempts. I desperately wanted Dupilumab to work and tried it several times but it barely took the edge of. I additionally tried Methatrexate injections on a couple of occasions but again the symptoms came back with a vengeance. So bad in fact that I questioned whether I could go on and thought I was done and needed to find a way out. I also tried Abrocinatib as they said it was doing well in the trials so I did a straight switch to it but the symptoms were horrendous again .

The symptoms I cannot cope with physically and mentally are when I am pouring with ooze, waking up in the morning next to my wife soaking wet with my pyjamas and bed sheets stuck to me, fiercely itchy all over, inflammation all over my body, burning and flaking away. This is my experience even after three and a half years without cyclosporine. 

There is a degree of symptoms which I can tolerate and certainly in the first year I tried taking the disease head on but after months and months of no progress cyclosporine gave me some life back. I initially felt like a failure as the internet is full of people who have healed from this disease and not used immunosuppressants. Resorting to using them makes you feel somewhat inadequate in comparison to them. 
However, I know I don't have the mental strength to not use them and I will not get through this without help. 

I honestly believed that nothing else could help but I was wrong. I have now been a on a new drug for two months called upadacitinib. I crossed the drugs over for three weeks to avoid a crash but for the first time in two and half or so years I have been able to come off cyclosporine. I am still in disbelief that this is the case. 

 I don't believe that any drug is ever going to be perfect. My skin is very dry and I still have rashes that present all over which are itchy but it doesn't seem to be that bone deep itch that you get with tsw. 

If you are in a similar position to me being forced off cyclosporine and losing hope that anything else will ever help or make a difference to the hellish symptoms,  I hope this article will give you some encouragement.

fields.title: Impossible decision.
fields.content:
In my last entry, which wasn't very long ago, I welcomed and praised the surprising effectiveness of Upadacinitib and it certainly works well in terms of clearing my skin. I wanted other people to know that for those who want or need medication to help with their symptoms there is something that helps other than cyclosporine. 

However, I had my quarterly appointment last Wednesday and all seemed well other than the fact that I seem to be gaining weight quite rapidly, despite taking measures to lose some. Regardless, I did my bloods as per usual. The following Monday I received a call from the nurse telling me that i needed to do a repeat blood test as one of my results wasn’t looking good. That was my liver. 

Before starting the drug my baseline liver level was 20 and they tell me the lower limit is 4 and the upper limit is 59. That morning she rang to tell me I had exceeded the upper limit and was on 63 but I didn’t need to worry at this stage and just needed to do another blood test. After having this follow up blood test my levels have gone up again to 74 and that is just over a week since my appointment. And yet still they want me to continue on this drug at the same dosage.I was informed that I could just choose to stop but there are not many options for me. What I don’t understand is why they will not try a lower dose of the drug. I really don’t understand this. I was even told it might be unrelated. Which of course it cannot be, nothing else has changed other than the introduction of the drug, therefore , this is certainly not a coincidence.She also asked me if I was a drinker. I haven’t had any alcohol since August 2018. I have indeed told them this many times.

Well at this point my mental health just crashed and I hit rock bottom. My liver obviously is not coping and there is not a strategy or any proactiveness in place to do something about this and I am supposed to just continue. I feel I am now faced with either driving my liver into the ground and having clear skin or allowing my liver to heal and suffering horrendously again. Just the thought of the latter throws up all the trauma of what I’ve been through and this option terrifies me. How can I possibly chose to wake up next to my wife soaking wet from ooze, sore and freezing cold ,only able to sleep in hot bath water, being tormented by a bone deep itch that tortures you to the very core of your being.The truth is I know I can’t face this again, not physically or mentally. The alternate option doesn’t look to good either. Running another organ into the ground and suffering the consequences of that. 

So, where do you begin to make such a decision. One thing I do know is that I do not want to procrastinate remaining undecided is a bad decision. To hope things will just improve on there own is just futile thinking and will lead me nowhere good. 

I still have hope in one day being free of this burden and I still have to take courage in the message from Dr Rapaport that this will come to an end. My healing objective still remains and I need help to get to the end. But how to move forward right now seems impossible.

fields.title: two-doctors
fields.content:
An Account of Two Doctors

Over two and a half years of this and I just haven’t made progress like so many others. It’s becoming hard to imagine a day without these symptoms despite using immuno’s to help. How can they still be so severe, why hasn’t my body shown me any sign that it will get on top of this.

In my desperation, I reached out to Dr R. My family payed for a retainer so i could benefit from his  tele-medical consultations. This provided some reasurrance as he reinforced the fact that he’d seen no failures to cure, although it can take many years, more than i ever thought. He told me that, where addiction was deeply set in it can take 3-5 years to cure. He reinforced the fact that i should trust the process, that i would get there. Precious words yet still i find it a struggle to believe when i look at how red my limbs are after 2 1/2 years. But what choice do i have  but to trust him, he tells me he had cures over 5000 patients. AS much as these words are precious and come from such a reliable source they did come at quite a hefty price. Just a warning if you are planning to use his services. 

As it stands i’ve been on cyclosporine for 2 years and i’m currently 31 months into tsw. This is a problem as Dermatologists in the UK don’t like to use it any longer than a year tops. The hospital i am currently an outpatient of is Guy’s in London. The team here work under the guidance of professor Smith. There have recently been some trials for a new type of drug to treat eczema, called JAKs and one that is supposed to be fast acting called abrocinitib. The professor recommended it to me as the way forward and a way to stop cyclsporine. She told me it was essential as she had psoriasis patients who have kidney injury from being long term users. So, Dr R says a stay on the drug, it is ok, professor Smith says got to get you off it. Well, as i am under Guy’s and cannot afford to continue with Dr Rapaport i am going to have to try this new option. 

These are difficult times, i don’t want to be in this situation at all. Every part of me feels i should be able to manage my symptoms without immunosuppressants now, but i can’t, every time i have tried to reduce the cyclo they come back so severe life just isn’t worth living and i just don’t want to be in my body any longer, i still flare head to toe.

 I told the P of my concerns and she said we have to get you in to do the transfer. This is where the battles began as they still use steroid creams heavily there. I’ve not found one derm who is supportive of our condition, you are more likely to be sniggered at then listened to. P Smith came in to one of my consultations and asked “what even is RSS?”. You see i have this diagnosis on my notes from another hospital. I could see she was elevated almost like she wanted a battle. I decided not to get to involved but give her my testimony of using the creams and oral pills for the last ten years and the utter mess they have left me in, I described how my condition deteriorated on them to the point of being red all over, unable to move for days at a time, with my skin burning,itching like hell, and oozing this repulsive smelling fluid. In no certain terms i said i would never go back to using them. 
At this point she left. This is such an insanely hard battle. RSS people are so sick and vulnerable we need love and care from out Dr’s, not a battle. Nevertheless this is the challenging circumstance so many of us find ourselves in. 

Nevertheless, i submitted myself to their care after emailing in advance my concerns that they would try and force be back on steroids if the new super jak inhibitor didn’t work. I received a call from a Dermatologist Dr Matthew to assure me they would go back to cyclo and not steroids if it goes badly due to my experience with steroids. I was foolish enough to believe him. After a few day’s in hospital i was confronted by a derm telling me all the patients that come in use steroid s and that i should not be closed minded to using them again for a short period. At this point i was distraught, i dared to believe they might actually honour my email detailing my fears. At this point, once again the P came in and also tried to persuade me to use them. I seriously felt as though i was being bullied by these Dr’s. I certainly no longer felt safe in their care. A further two nurses also tried to persuade me to use them. Seriously, how is this still going with all the horrendous suffering these creams are causing. It just feels like nothing is ever going to change if this is how one of the ‘best’
hospitals for skin conditions uses them. 

Anyway, i stopped the cyclo and started abrocinitib and within two days I was in agony, pouring with ooze and scratching like crazy. The professor came in, with Dr Matthew (the Dr who assured me on the phone i wouldn’t be pushed into steroids agaon) and I begged her to let me back on cyclo to which she initially replied, no. I was in such a state and desperate i was literally pleading. She told me once again, now for the third time i needed topical steroids. What an unbelievable fight to get my health back, just unbelievable. I said no and she accused me of tying their hands behind their backs. After imploring her over and over she finally agreed to let me go back on it for now. 
Here a am 5 days later still in a horrific mess, just from two days of stopping cyclo. I've barely been able to move i’m in so much pain, particularly my thighs and arms.

I know many people who suffer with tsw do not like to go near immunosuppressants but i just feel like i need them to function. So this is the ordeal i’ve faced over the last two weeks. Just want this to be over, this disease is harrowing and we have to fight so hard and do not get any where near the levels of care and support we desperatley need.
